content.webTitle: Manuel Pellegrini admits Manchester City must tighten up defensively

fields.headline: Manuel Pellegrini admits Manchester City must tighten up defensively
fields.bodyText: Manuel Pellegrini smiled at Robin van Persie’s late equaliser for Manchester United against Chelsea. Chelsea appeared set to stretch their advantage over the champions to eight points before the Dutchman’s late intervention at Old Trafford on Sunday. “I don’t remember,” said Pellegrini initially when asked if he laughed at the strike. “At that moment, I thought the game was finished and I went to drink a glass of water.” Yet pushed, he admitted: “When they told me after how the game finished I smiled.” Last Tuesday City allowed a two-goal lead at CSKA Moscow to slip as they drew 2-2 in a vital Champions League game, before going down 2-1 at West Ham United on Saturday. In each match City’s defence was vulnerable, as it has been on other occasions this term. Pellegrini has been doing extra work on the rearguard. “I think it’s very important to have clean sheets,” he said. “As a team you play easily or you play with more trust when you don’t concede any easy goal at the beginning. Then you start playing against the result, against the time, against the other team. A lot of things. “But I think we must improve in general, not just the talking about the defending. We must create more chances, we must score more goals. We are working on that and I am absolutely sure we will return to be the same team we were in the most important part of last season. But the only way is to compare last season with this season. And I don’t think we are any worse this season.” Vincent Kompany has had to adjust at times to Eliaquim Mangala being his partner in central defence instead of Martín Demichelis. Yet Pellegrini denied this was a factor in the unsure defence. “The same happened with Demichelis last year – remember all the criticism for him after he just arrived in the Premier League,” he said. “Vincent was playing sometime with Martín, sometimes with Joleon Lescott, sometimes with Matija Nastasic. “I think Eliaquim Mangala is a young player, he has a lot of experience. And I am sure we bought the centre-back that we need in him. This year with him, with Vincent, Martin, Nastasic and Dedryck Boyata we have a centre-backs that I can assure you will play very well.” Wayne Rooney’s fitness is in the balance for Sunday’s 168th Mancunian derby at the Etihad Stadium, though Pellegrini denied City would make any particular plans for United’s captain should he play. “No. We really don’t change our way to play for some player, or other player. If it’s not Wayne Rooney it will be Ángel di María, Juan Mata or Robin van Persie,” he said. “They have so many creative players that they have a lot of different chances [to score]. We cannot prepare for a game talking about one player. Because after it can happen that he doesn’t play and we have to change all of what we do. We really try to have a style of play every game. I am sure Wayne Rooney is one of the important players of Manchester United but I repeat, also other players are very difficult for us.” After Newcastle United’s visit on Wednesday evening in the Capital One Cup, and United at the weekend, CSKA arrive for the return Champions League match. Pellegrini admits these are three vital matches in a week. “I think we must win the three games,” he said. “They are three competitions. If we win tomorrow we will continue in the Capital One Cup. If we win the derby on Sunday we are trying to go for first place in the table. And if we win next Wednesday we are going to take a huge step to qualifying in the Champions League. So they are three games that are very important and I am sure the squad is prepared to do it.” Samir Nasri returns to City’s squad after recovering ahead of schedule from a groin injury. Newcastle are likely to be without Papiss Cissé but Ryan Taylor could make his first appearance since August 2012 after two cruciate injuries. Sami Hyypia comes up against familiar foes on Wednesday when he takes his Brighton side to Tottenham. Hyypia regularly faced Spurs during his successful 10 years as a centre-half with Liverpool. The Finn is finding management in England rather tougher, with Brighton one place above the relegation zone after 10 Championship matches without a win. However, Hyypia has urged his struggling side to play with no fear at White Hart Lane. “It’s very important that we concentrate on how we play there and how we present ourselves,” he told the Argus. “We need to have the courage; we don’t have to fear them. They have good individuals and they can really hurt you if they are on top of their game but we don’t have to fear them.” The winger Kazenga LuaLua is back in the squad after a one-match ban but Sam Baldock is cup-tied. Another striker, Craig Mackail-Smith, could miss out with a hamstring injury and the right-back Bruno is struggling with groin trouble. Stoke have changed their tactics for defending set-pieces over concerns that Ryan Shawcross is being singled out by referees. The Stoke captain gave away a penalty in the 2-1 win over Swansea this month for grappling with Wilfried Bony and was deployed at Southampton last weekend as a zonal defender. The assistant manager, Mark Bowen said: “In Saturday’s game we tried to pull him out of the spotlight. Instead of him actually marking from a corner, we put him in an area where he could just go and attack the ball, which is not his game – he’s not been brought up on that. “It comes to something when you’ve got to try to change your system of marking around because you’re worried that the lad is getting targeted.” Stoke fear they may be without Robert Huth for several weeks because of a calf injury. Southampton’s manager, Ronald Koeman, is expecting another tough game after the 1-0 win over these opponents on Saturday. He may rest some key players but insists he will not make wholesale changes.
